rates.keyEvent: Tariff Act of 1789 – first federal tariff (~5%) (estimated)
Tariff Act of 1816 (Dallas Tariff) raised rates (~20-25%) for revenue and protection (estimated)
Tariff of Abominations (1828) – high protective tariff (~49%), sparking nullification tensions
Walker Tariff (1846) dramatically cut rates (free-trade shift, estimated)
Morrill Tariff (1861) – raised duties (~36%) as Civil War loomed
Civil War peak tariffs (~48% on dutiables) to fund war
McKinley Tariff Act (1890) – raised average dutiable rate to ~49%
Underwood Tariff (1913) – lowered rates and introduced income tax (estimated)
Smoot–Hawley Tariff (1930) – significant increase (~44.9% on dutiable imports)
Projected tariffs ~27.0% in 2025 (second Trump presidency, estimated)

keyLegislation.name: Tariff Act of 1789
keyLegislation.description: Imposed ~5% duties on most imports as first major tariff law
keyLegislation.impact: Provided primary revenue for new government and modest protection to U.S. industries

keyLegislation.name: Tariff Act of 1816 (Dallas Tariff)
keyLegislation.description: First explicitly protective tariff, raising rates ~20-25%
keyLegislation.impact: Stimulated domestic manufacturing and generated revenue; fostered sectional tensions

keyLegislation.name: Tariff of 1828 (Tariff of Abominations)
keyLegislation.impact: Protected Northern industry but hurt the South; led to Nullification Crisis and higher consumer prices

keyLegislation.name: Compromise Tariff of 1833
keyLegislation.description: Gradual tariff reductions over 1833-1842 to quell nullification
keyLegislation.impact: Defused South Carolina crisis by slowly lowering rates; stabilized prices and political climate

keyLegislation.name: Tariff Act of 1846 (Walker Tariff)
keyLegislation.impact: Lowered average rates, boosted imports and revenue; supported economic growth and lowered prices

keyLegislation.name: Morrill Tariff Act (1861)
keyLegislation.description: Raised duties sharply to fund Civil War
keyLegislation.impact: Doubled rates, generating crucial war revenue and protecting U.S. industry; increased consumer prices

keyLegislation.name: McKinley Tariff Act (1890)
keyLegislation.description: Imposed very high tariffs (~49%) on many imports
keyLegislation.impact: Protected U.S. manufacturers but raised consumer prices; contributed to farmer discontent and political backlash

keyLegislation.name: Underwood Tariff Act (1913)
keyLegislation.description: Lowered tariff rates and established federal income tax
keyLegislation.impact: Reduced import duties, lowering prices and expanding trade; shifted government revenue base to income tax

keyLegislation.name: Smoot–Hawley Tariff Act (1930)
keyLegislation.description: Massive tariff increases on thousands of goods
keyLegislation.impact: Contributed to trade wars and deepened the Great Depression; U.S. exports fell sharply, prices rose

keyLegislation.name: Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act (1934)
keyLegislation.description: Authorized presidential negotiation of tariff reductions
keyLegislation.impact: Initiated modern tariff liberalization, reversing some Smoot–Hawley duties; facilitated trade expansion and economic recovery

keyLegislation.name: General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT)
keyLegislation.description: Multilateral agreement reducing tariffs globally after WWII
keyLegislation.impact: Opened markets and lowered tariffs through successive rounds; spurred postwar trade growth and U.S. GDP expansion

keyLegislation.name: Trade Expansion Act of 1962
keyLegislation.description: Authorized tariff cuts (Kennedy Round) to boost trade
keyLegislation.impact: Led to across-the-board tariff reductions, expanded exports, and slightly lower import prices

keyLegislation.name: Trade Act of 1974
keyLegislation.description: Established fast-track negotiation authority for tariffs
keyLegislation.impact: Facilitated major trade agreements (e.g. Tokyo Round), promoting further tariff cuts and international trade

keyLegislation.name: North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA)
keyLegislation.impact: Greatly increased North American trade flows; modest GDP gains, shifts in jobs across sectors

keyLegislation.name: World Trade Organization (WTO, 1995)
keyLegislation.description: Created to enforce global trade rules after Uruguay Round
keyLegislation.impact: Committed member countries to lower tariffs; helped lower U.S. tariff and import prices and expand trade

economicImpacts.employmentEffect: Growth in manufacturing and infrastructure jobs as tariffs financed government and protected industries
economicImpacts.priceEffect: Moderate inflation during war years; generally stable prices

economicImpacts.employmentEffect: Rapid industrial expansion, especially in the North; agricultural employment remained high in the South
economicImpacts.priceEffect: Generally low inflation, occasional deflation under the gold standard

economicImpacts.employmentEffect: Manufacturing output surged for war, labor mobilized; many men in military reduced civilian workforce
economicImpacts.priceEffect: High inflation due to war spending

economicImpacts.employmentEffect: Booming industrial and railroad jobs; immigration fueled labor force
economicImpacts.priceEffect: Low inflation (gold standard); prices generally stable or falling

economicImpacts.employmentEffect: Massive unemployment (Great Depression peaked ~25%); slump in manufacturing jobs
Full employment; strong growth in manufacturing and services
Decline in manufacturing jobs; rise in services; expanding international trade
economicImpacts.priceEffect: High inflation in 1970s (OPEC shocks), moderating to ~3% by 1990s

economicImpacts.employmentEffect: Globalized supply chains; trade war tensions (2018-2021) caused some job shifts
economicImpacts.priceEffect: Lower import prices through 2010s; some inflationary pressure on goods prices by 2025
